Award.AwardTitle: The Distribution and Evolution of the Gas and Dust Content of Protoplanetary Disks
Award.AbstractNarration: The researchers conduct millimeter-wavelength interferometry of CO (and related isotopologues) gas and dust emission from circumstellar disks that are at different stages of growth. The PI and his research team will also model the molecular chemistry and radiative transfer for each disk in order to estimate mass as a function of time. The new mass estimates will be used to constrain models of disk and planetary formation and evolution. He plans to use the Submillimeter Array (SMA) on Mauna Kea, and ALMA. A graduate student at University of Hawaii-Manoa, undergraduate student at University of Hawaii at Hilo and student in the Research Experiences for Undergraudates (REU) summer program will also participate in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award allowed the PI and graduate students to carry out innovative new studies of planet-forming disks around nearby stars. Using the Submillimeter telescope array (SMA) on Maunake, Hawaii, we measured the spectral line emission from isotopologues of carbon monoxide in 9 disks in the nearby Taurus association. The interpretation of the results required the development of new models, from which we showed that the mass of gas in these disks was much lower than expected. This new finding may explain why extrasolar planets tend to be rocky super-Earths or gas-poor Neptunes rather than gas-rich Jupiters. We then expanded the study using the recently commissioned Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) in Chile to a much larger sample of 82 disks in the southern Lupus star-forming region. This is the largest study of its kind to date and the statistical weight is leading to new investigations of disk chemistry, structure, and the dependence of properties with the mass of the central star. These provide new and important insights for theories of planet formation. Three graduate students working toward a PhD dissertation were partially funded through the four years of funding. They were trained in the acquisition and analysis of millimeter interferometry, computing coding in python, writing scientific papers, and presentation of results at meetings. The PI and students authored a total of 18 peer-reviewed papers during this time.
